While it is definitely important to choose a drug that is affordable and has tolerable side effects, we know nothing about the other drugs or about Dr. Jones' patients.  Drug A is safe, effective, and affordable, and it has tolerable side effects.  That makes it appropriate to prescribe, in my opinion.  However, are the other drugs safer, more effective, or more affordable?  Do they have fewer or more tolerable side effects?  Are Dr. Jones' patients more susceptible to the side effects of Drug A than the other drugs?  Have they had good or bad results with any of the approved drugs or with similar medications in the past?  Without knowing these things, I can't say whether prescribing Drug A is *very* appropriate or not.

On one hand, sticking with what works in your experience is good in many cases but on the other, people respond differently to things so not good to limit your options like that.

The test procedures seem fair and ethical. However, the experiment doesn't seem to take into account the fact that different individuals respond differently to medications. Some patients might do better with Medication A than Medication B, even if the majority of patients have the most positive results with Medication B. the consumers can handle the side effects, so he's just choosing which is best to give to all.

Often there are medical or other reasons why one effective drug should be chosen over another.  And a drug that is effective for one patient may be inexplicably ineffective on another. The side effects are manageable and the price of the drug is affordable, but I didn't choose very appropriate because I feel as though the doctor may be doing his patients a disservice by not trying to adjust their diet and exercise to combat the high blood pressure naturally.

I think doctor Jones wants the best for his patients. He chose an affordable drug that won't harm them. Very wise man.
